item.title: S&P 500 Gains as US Jobs Holding Up Amid Trade War: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street traders drove stocks higher as data showed the US labor market is holding up despite concerns about risks stemming from President Donald Trump’s tariff war. Bonds fell. The dollar rose.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: The Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index edged down 0.2 point last month to 48.5. The ISM’s import measure dropped 7.2 points, one of the largest monthly slides on record, to 39.9. Mike McKee reports on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Corrects to show third month of contraction)

item.title: Russia Says Power Restored in Ukraine’s Occupied Regions
item.description: Russia said power had been returned to two Ukrainian regions it partially occupies after damage to infrastructure left more than 700,000 households without electricity.
item.dc:creator: Liezel Hill

media:content.media:description: KHERSON, UKRAINE - OCTOBER 3: Electric power transmission lines stand on October 3, 2023 in Kherson, Ukraine. From March to November 2022, Kherson was occupied by Russian forces during their full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Ukrainian forces recaptured the city on November 11, 2022. In June 2023, the city was flooded following the destruction of the nearby Kakhovka Dam. Russian military continues to systematically shell Kherson. (Photo by Yurii Stefanyak/Global Images Ukraine via Getty Images)

item.title: Emerging-Market Currencies Fall, Weighed Down by Dollar Bounce
item.description: A wide swath of emerging-market currencies fell Tuesday, weighed down by a bounce in the dollar.
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Butler, Leda Alvim

media:content.media:description: Stock market information.

item.title: Ecuador Vows a Return to Debt Markets, Sending Bonds Soaring
item.description: Beaten down Ecuador bonds jumped the most among emerging-market peers on Tuesday after the nation’s top finance officer said the government plans to return to capital markets next year.
item.dc:creator: Stephan Kueffner, Zijia Song

media:content.media:description: The central bank building in Quito, Ecuador.

item.title: Haagen-Dazs Maker Froneri to Raise €4 Billion Debt as PAI Seeks to Keep Stake
item.description: Ice cream maker Froneri Ltd. is seeking around €4 billion ($4.6 billion) in debt to support a fund that would let co-owner PAI Partners hold onto its stake in the Nestle SA-backed joint venture and facilitate a dividend payment, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Claire Ruckin

media:content.media:description: Cups of US ice cream brand Haagen-Dazs, are seen on a production line on December 8, 2017 in a plant in Tilloy-les-Mofflaines, northern France. / AFP PHOTO / Denis Charlet (Photo credit should read DENIS CHARLET/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: AQR’s Cliff Asness Hails Return of ‘Basic Rational Investing’
item.description: Years of speculative excess are giving way to healthier markets where fundamentals now matter, boosting quant stock-picking strategies across the board, according to AQR Capital Management’s Cliff Asness.
item.dc:creator: Sonali Basak, Justina Lee

media:content.media:description: Cliff Asness, chief investment officer of AQR Capital Management LLC, during the Bloomberg Invest event in New York, US, on Tuesday, June 25, 2024. The conference invites leaders in asset management, banking, wealth, and private markets to track, dissect, and predict the future's greatest changes, risks and opportunities.

item.title: Marathon's Richards Sees Blockbuster Moment for Non-AI Software
item.description: Marathon Asset Management founder and CEO Bruce Richards says the software sector is giving him "some pause" on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Alberta Fire Threat Stabilizes as Rain Slows Some Blazes’ Growth
item.description: Alberta’s wildfire threat stabilized as rain slowed the growth of some blazes that have forced evacuations and shut about 7% of Canada’s daily oil production.
item.dc:creator: Robert Tuttle, Brian K Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from Edith Lake wildfire SWF076, which forced the evacuation of the nearby town of Swan Hills, Alberta, Canada.

item.title: Berro: Fed Can Wait and See Given Current Data
item.description: Fixed Income Portfolio Manager for J.P. Morgan Asset Management, Kelsey Berro, discusses job data and it's impact on the Fed with Bloomberg's Matt Miller on "Bloomberg Brief." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Uruguay’s DLocal Agrees to Buy AZA Finance in Africa Push
item.description: DLocal Ltd. has reached an agreement to buy African payments provider AZA Finance, as the emerging markets payments firm looks to accelerate growth outside of its stronghold of Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Ken Parks, Liana Baker

media:content.media:description: The DLocal logo

item.title: Industrial Metals Slip as China PMI Hits Lowest Level Since 2022
item.description: Industrial metals drifted lower amid concerns about China’s economic outlook, after a gauge of the country’s manufacturing activity fell to its lowest level in more than two years.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell, Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: Iron ore falls onto stockpiles at the Fortescue Metals Group Ltd. Cloudbreak mine in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, Australia, on Tuesday, Oct. 17, 2023. Chinese demand for Australian iron ore will remain strong despite the nation’s disappointing post-pandemic recovery, according to Fortescue Metals, the world’s fourth-biggest producer. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Gasoline Price Drop Offset by Fuel-Levy Hike
item.description: South Africa’s first fuel-levy hike in four years offset a drop in gasoline and diesel prices after a court dismissed an urgent application to stop the increase.
item.dc:creator: Katlego Mtshali

media:content.media:description: Gas pumps at a fuel station in Pretoria, South Africa.

item.title: Energy, Tech Lead US Stocks Gains on Healthy Jobs Data, Earnings
item.description: US equities shrugged off initial jitters to climb on Tuesday, buoyed by a report signaling a healthy job market and a string of positive corporate news.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: US Efforts to Boost Crop Sales to Asia Bear Fruit in Vietnam
item.description: US efforts to increase exports of agricultural products to Asia, excluding China, look to be bearing fruit, with Vietnam pledging to buy more American goods to strengthen trade ties with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Gu

media:content.media:description: A corn harvest in Leland, Mississippi, US. Photographer: Rory Doyle/Bloomberg

item.title: French Senate Amends Fast-Fashion Bill to Target Shein, Temu
item.description: French senators are seeking to sharpen planned legislation aimed at regulating fast fashion to target sellers of ultra-cheap clothing such as Chinese-founded Shein Group Ltd. and Temu.
item.dc:creator: Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Packages from Shein in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Marathon's Richards on Treasuries, Fed and Software Stocks
item.description: Marathon Asset Management founder and CEO Bruce Richards discusses the outlook for financial markets, Federal Reserve monetary policy and how he is investing in the current environment on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Key US Oil Gauges Strengthen as Canada Fires Imperil Vital Flows
item.description: Key gauges of US oil market strength are soaring as wildfires in Canada risk flows to critical American storage hubs, limiting the impact of OPEC+ supply increases.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: A wildfire labeled HWF040 is burning east of La Crete Ferry in Alberta, Canada

item.title: Fed Is on an Extended Hold, Marathon's Richards Says
item.description: Marathon Asset Management founder and CEO Bruce Richards says inflation is "well behaved" and the Federal Reserve will keep rates where they are now on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: France Says Positive Outcome Possible in Cognac Probe Talks With China
item.description: France’s trade minister said he believes Beijing and Paris can resolve a spat over duties on Cognac that is hammering French producers and complicating broader discussions on global commerce.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Bottles of French cognac displayed at an independent winegrowers fair in Paris, France, on Friday, March 21, 2025. A sector-by-sector tariff approach by US President Donald Trump risks creating divisions among European Union member states, Micheal Martin, Ireland's prime minister, said.

item.title: Palm Beach Housing Crunch Spurs $236 Million Muni Deal for Dorms
item.description: Student housing is so tight at Palm Beach Atlantic University that some applicants have chosen not to enroll. A $235.8 million high-yield bond deal is the school’s bet to reverse that trend.
item.dc:creator: Arvelisse Bonilla Ramos

media:content.media:description: A rendering of a residential building to be built at Palm Beach Atlantic University. Source: Provident Resources Group

item.title: Asness on Buying Opportunities, Markets, Tarirffs
item.description: Cliff Asness, AQR Capital Management founder, talks about the current state of markets, his investing philosophy, where he sees buying opportunities and how President Donald Trump's policies could impact investors. He is on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: KKR Builds Record $42 Billion Private Real Estate Loan Pipeline
item.description: KKR & Co. has a record volume of commercial-property financings lined up, and expects more deals as property prices reset and other lenders pull back amid market volatility.
item.dc:creator: Georgia Hall

media:content.media:description: Real estate signage on an empty commercial building on Fourth Avenue in Seattle.

item.title: Gazprom Abandons Idea of Turkish Backdoor to Europe’s Gas Market
item.description: Russia’s Gazprom PJSC has quietly shelved plans to develop a new gas distribution hub in Turkey, closing the door on a potential opportunity to regain a foothold in European markets lost since the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

media:content.media:description: A Gazprom-branded protective end cap on a gas pipe. Source: Andrey Rudakov

item.title: BlackRock's Chaudhuri on the AI Trade and Software Stocks
item.description: Gargi Chaudhuri, BlackRock chief investment and portfolio strategist, Americas, discusses the outlook for AI and software stocks on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Investec Says Sluggish Growth Has Cost South Africa $251 Billion
item.description: South Africa’s economy is 37% smaller than it would have been had the country tracked its emerging-market peers and sustained annual growth of 4.5% since 2010, a report by Investec Wealth & Investment International said.
item.dc:creator: Adelaide Changole

media:content.media:description: A resident surveys the central business district in Johannesburg, South Africa.

item.title: US Job Openings Increase to 7.39 Million in April
item.description: US job openings unexpectedly rose in April, increasing to 7.39 million from a revised 7.20 million reading in March, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics data published Tuesday. Katie Greifeld reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Oil Extends Gains as Canada Wildfires Offset OPEC+ Output Hike
item.description: Oil rose for a second day as supply disruptions from Canada’s wildfires countered OPEC’s latest bumper supply increase.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: A pumpjack in Martin County, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch. Photographer: Justin Hamel/Bloomberg

item.title: BHP-Backed Startup Delivers First Copper at Chile Leaching Plant
item.description: A Chilean startup backed by BHP Group has delivered its first copper cathodes from a demonstration plant at a mine site in northern Chile as the industry looks to squeeze out more metal from lower quality ore.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

media:content.media:description: Copper cathode sheets at the KGHM Polska Miedz SA copper smelter in Glogow, Poland, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. Poland’s government reduced its economic growth target for this year, citing external risks such as US trade policies and the war in Ukraine. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese EV Maker Nio to Reduce R&D Costs to Hit Break-Even Goal
item.description: Nio Inc. aims to reduce research and development spending by as much as 25% as it seeks to reach its break-even target by the fourth quarter.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo

media:content.media:description: Nio Inc. electric vehicles move through a production line at the company's factory in Hefei, China.

item.title: NYC’s Noisy Skies Get Electric With Beta’s Demo Flight Into JFK
item.description: New York City will probably never rid itself of the thousands of helicopters heard flying around tourists and bigwigs each day, but one company is promising a quieter alternative.
item.dc:creator: Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: A BETA Technologies Inc. CX300 aircraft flying near New York.
